name: Los Angeles
intro_vibe: A network of micro-cities connected by freeways, ambition, and tacos.

general_info.description: Los Angeles is not a single city; it is a massive collection of distinct neighborhoods. From the grit of Hollywood to the zen of Malibu and the hipster hills of Silver Lake. It is a city defined by its diversity, its car culture, and its creative energy. Don't try to 'see it all'—pick a neighborhood and live in it.

etiquette_tips: The Distance Reality: Do not trust miles. Trust time. 10 miles can take 1 hour. Never plan more than 2 major neighborhoods in one day.
Parking Signs are Hostile: Read the sign. Then read the other sign. Then read the red curb. Parking tickets are a major revenue source for the city.
Soft Status: People don't flash wealth with suits. The person in sweatpants and a vintage t-shirt might be a studio executive. Don't judge by appearance.
Dinner is at 8pm: Restaurants are busy late. Reservations are essential for popular spots (often weeks in advance).
Health is Infrastructure: Everyone hikes, everyone drinks green juice, and dietary restrictions (Vegan, Gluten-Free) are accommodated everywhere without question.
Tipping: 18-20% is the minimum standard. Valets get $2-5. Bartenders get $1-2 per drink.

essential_phrases.phonetic: The four-oh-five (Always add 'The' before freeway names)

neighborhoods.name: Silver Lake & Echo Park
neighborhoods.description: The hills of East LA. Vintage stores, independent coffee shops, steep staircases, and a very localized community feel. Very walkable strips.

neighborhoods.name: Santa Monica
neighborhoods.description: The polished, walkable beach city. Great for first-timers, families, and shopping. The Pier is touristy, but the Main Street area is local.

neighborhoods.name: West Hollywood (WeHo)
neighborhoods.description: The party center. Legendary rock clubs on the Sunset Strip and the vibrant LGBTQ+ district on Santa Monica Blvd. High energy and walkable.

neighborhoods.name: Arts District (DTLA)
neighborhoods.description: Converted warehouses filled with breweries, galleries, and high-end dining. Gritty but rapidly gentrifying. Great for foodies.

logistics.title: Local Survival Tips
details: The Uber Strategy: Don't wait until you leave the venue to call a car. Call it 10 minutes early. Wait times can be long.
Jaywalking: It was recently decriminalized, but cars still won't stop for you. Be careful.
Sunsets: The sun sets over the ocean. Plan your day to end facing West for the view.
Reservations: For dinner, 'walking in' is risky. Use Resy or OpenTable.

logistics.title: Getting Around
logistics.summary: You probably need a car, but Uber is viable for short trips.
details: Car Rental: Essential if you want to see Malibu, hiking trails, or multiple neighborhoods in one day.
Uber/Lyft: Reliable but expensive due to distances. Great for nights out.
The Metro: The Expo Line (Downtown to Santa Monica) is actually useful and avoids traffic. The rest is hit-or-miss.
Walking: Only possible WITHIN neighborhoods (e.g., walking around Silver Lake). You cannot walk BETWEEN neighborhoods.

logistics.title: Safety Basics
logistics.summary: LA is safe, but has distinct 'Skid Row' zones.
details: Skid Row: Avoid the area East of Main St in Downtown LA. It is a humanitarian crisis zone.
Hollywood at Night: The tourist strip gets gritty and aggressive after dark.
Car Valuables: Never leave bags visible in your car. Smash-and-grabs happen, even in nice areas.

must_eat.description: Eating in a parking lot is peak LA dining. Look for 'Leo's Taco Truck' (Al Pastor) or 'Mariscos Jalisco' (Fried Shrimp Tacos). Cash only.
Not just BBQ. Try Soondubu (tofu stew) at BCD, or cold noodles. K-Town is a 24-hour food city within a city.
The California classic. Order a 'Double-Double Animal Style' (grilled onions + extra sauce). It is fast food, but it is fresh and legendary.
Where the chefs shop. The Wednesday Santa Monica market is world-famous. Get fresh berries, pastries, and prepared food.
LA is currently obsessed with lacy, crispy smashburgers. Look for 'Burgers Never Say Die' or pop-ups in parking lots.
Spicy stewed beef tacos dipped in consommé. LA made this global. Teddy's Red Tacos is a reliable spot.
Historic food hall downtown. Try 'Eggslut' for breakfast or 'Sarita's' for Pupusas. Crowded but iconic.

items.description: The 'social hike'. Great city views, lots of dogs, and maybe a celebrity sighting. Wear workout gear, not hiking boots.
The best view in LA, period. See the Hollywood Sign and the entire basin. Go at sunset. Parking is tough, take the shuttle.
Dramatic cliffs and sea caves. Far more beautiful than Santa Monica beach. A bit of a drive, but worth it.
Resting place of stars, but also a cultural hub. They host outdoor movie screenings (Cinespia) on the lawn in summer.
World-class art, stunning architecture, and gardens on a hill. Free entry (pay for parking). The tram ride up is part of the fun.
The most authentic studio tour. See real working sets, the 'Friends' fountain, and the Batmobile collection.
End of Route 66. Touristy, yes, but the Ferris wheel at sunset is iconic. Walk or bike down to Venice Beach from here.
Honest review: It is crowded and gritty. See the stars, see the Chinese Theatre footprints, and then leave for West Hollywood.

affiliate_products.title: US Travel Adapter (Type A/B)
affiliate_products.reason: US plugs have two flat pins. If you're from Europe, you need an adapter.

affiliate_products.title: Sunscreen SPF 50
affiliate_products.reason: The California sun is strong, even when it feels cool. Wear it driving, hiking, and walking.

affiliate_products.title: Hiking Water Bottle
affiliate_products.reason: LA is dry and hot. You need water constantly, especially if you hike Runyon or Griffith.
